text:
Appearance: somewhat hazy darker copper. Thin head of white bubbles.
Nose: medium roasted malt. Hints of caramel, earthy hops and roasted grains
Taste: well roasted cereal, hints of nuts. Just a touch of sweetness and crisp herbal hops.
Body: Medium to thinner and lively. 
Parting thoughts: A very nice Oktoberfest from ballast point. well done.

Thin off-white head of fine bubbles with light carbonation. Gingerbread, roasted malts, cake donuts and some brown sugar. Color is a dark crimson brown. Sickly sweet malts, tea leaves, roasted grains and a bit of dry chalkiness late swallow. Mild alcohol presence. Finished dry and pasty with a bit of lingering bitter tea. Eh, palatable.

Translucent brown with beige head. Medium body with high carbonation.

Aroma: toasted nuts, brown bread, caramel, spent grain, chalky minerality.

Taste: bready munich malt, sharp minerals, herbal hops, soft warm alcohol; with notes of toasted and roasted malts, coffee, hay bales, and caramel.

Seems like it has much more specialty malt usage than most traditional examples.

12oz bottle at The Bayou 
Pours clear dark amber with a medium sized beige head, good lacing. Aroma is toasted malts, bready, nutty and dark fruit. Flavor is malty, caramel, pine and citrus 
Tasty

Bottle. Deep amber body with a short, frothy, off-white head. Malty aroma of bread, toasted grain, herbs, overripe fruit, caramel. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. Medium body, watery/sticky texture, lively carbonation. Somewhat Ayinger like in flavor  malty, caramel, fruit. Too bad it has a raw grain aftertaste.

Where and how:  tasting @ VB 12 oz 
Aroma: Grassy with good malts. Nicely balancing rounded Noble Hops. Solid character presented. A bit Helles Bock like.
 Appearance : 
Top: medium tanned top, rings on glass. <br
Base: clear amber going into light brown
Palate :  medium bodied, thinner at walls. Average carbonation, average finish. Side more dry than mid.
Taste: malty, with darker malts feel, bread with tea. Dunkler bock Marzen hybrid.
 other notes  Tasty!
Bottle. Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel grainy aroma. Fruity malty grainy caramel bitter flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy caramel bitter finish.

Bottle. It pours dark amber with a beige head. The aroma has dark roasted roasty, molasses and lager roundness. It has a medium smooth body with mellow carbonation. The taste has roasted malt, brown sugar, dried bread and dry caramel. Pretty nice.

Great looking beer.. dark brown, clear, foamy big head. 4.5/5 on appearance. Smells of fall spices, malt.. a little bit malt heavy. Taste is very much neutral.. some malt, some spiciness.. a little fizzy, a little bitter... but smooth and creamy.

bottle @ Keg Liquors / Clarksville IN --- Aroma of earth and hay. Clear brown color, beige head that sinks to a full cover, wide lace bands. Taste is toasted malt with toffee, medium fizz, and a wee bit of hop bittering in a short finish. Leans toward sweet overall, but very easy to drink and satisfying.

On tap at World of Beer (Charlottesville, VA). Earthy aromas, forest, light cocoa, light cherry. Clear bronze with a lasting off-white head. Subtly sweet, toasty, raisiny, caramel, forest-earthy. Medium bodied, full flavored but very clean.
Draft pours Amber with a white head. Aroma of toffee and caramel. Taste is caramel and grains.

355 ml bottle. Clear deep copper, fading tan foam. Aroma and taste of rich sweet toasted caramel/toffee malt, subtle boozy fruity tang. Average carbonation, medium bodied, low hopped. LBW (Lagerboys Be Wary)
Bottle. Amber in Color with a three finger head. Aroma is roasted grains with a tad of hay and grass. Taste is a nicely balanced märzen beer.
Pours amber with an off white head. Aromas of malt and some caramel. Taste the same with a little sweetness from the malt. Nice example of an Oktoberfest beer. Little to no lacing in the glass.
Bottle from Liquor Barn. Appearance is reddish brown with a bit of white head. Aroma is toffee malts and taste is sweet.

Aroma - is definitely more malty than hopped. The malt is a cross between biscuit and caramel.
Appearance - the body is a clean mahogany, with some small nucleation. The head is beige, and about 1/2", the slowly fades into a nice layer of foam.
Taste - has caramel malt, some biscuity nature, and some gentle Bavarian hops.
Palate - medium body, smooth texture, average carbonation, and a tannic sort finish.

12 ounce bottle into dimpled mug, bottled on 8/8/2016. Pours crystal clear dark reddish copper/light brown color with a 1 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, light toffee, floral, grass, light pepper, and herbal/toasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt and light-moderate earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of big caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, light toffee, floral, grass, light pepper, and herbal/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, light toffee, floral, grass, pepper, and herbal/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light dryness from bitterness, increasing through the glass. Very clean on lager flavors, with minimal yeast notes present. Medium carbonation and medium-plus body; with a very smooth, creamy/bready, and lightly sticky balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Minimal warming alcohol as expected of 6%. Overall this is a very nice Oktoberfest style. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; very smooth and easy to drink. A bit hoppy for the style, but not overdone; and has a plenty of rich malt flavors to balance it out. A very enjoyable offering.
Pours a true copper brown color with a toffee aroma. Taste is light nut, with a caramel amd toffee flavor. Mild bitterness with a light malt aftertaste.
Bottle from Beer and Wine. Dark brown body with medium head. Nose is sweet, malty, vanilla. Taste is toasty, caramel and malts. More subdued in the finish with hoppy, citrus notes. Quite enjoyable.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear ruby red color with a finger-thick off-white head. Aroma is sweet malt with no hop presence. Medium body, taste is all malt with very little hops. Clean finish, a little sweet. Excellent!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a four finger dark cream head that fades slowly leaving some lace. Crystal clear deep amber color. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Light malty nose, flavor is malty, hints of caramel. Light bitter finish. $2.35 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, MA.
what a malty caramely mess. too much malt, sweet and a strange terrible aroma. not my style at all. i hate october. pours reddish brown with almost no head. had out of a bottle at home. meh.

Bottle. Poured clear dark brownish copper color with an average to large frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate toasted sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium toasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

Bottle: &nbsp Dull dark amber, frothy off-white head, nice lacing. &nbsp Sweet bready nose, a touch of caramel. &nbsp Sweet and bready up front. &nbsp Very clean, and much fuller than most other examples. &nbsp Moderate to full body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Finishes with a sweet caramel breadiness. &bnsp Very easy to drink, and much less grainy and soily as compared to others. &nbsp A good Oktoberfest that beats the crap out of most in its league.

Deep Amber orange brown with little Beige head; aroma is sweetish malty subtle hop spice; flava is grainy sweet with notes of caramel apple; feels medium to light with decent fizz; finishes mildly grainy and sweet

12 oz bottle- Pours dark caramel with a light tan medium head that holds very nicely. Aroma is caramel malts, grains, a bit of fruitiness. The taste is pretty much a traditional Oktoberfest, strong caramel malts and toffee, grains, medium light bitterness. Good, not too sweet, well balanced.

Bottle:
Clear, deep copper-red with a thin tan head.
Toasted bread, caramel scent.
Rich, slightly sweet caramel malt, butter.....mild earthy/alcohol bitter....a touch of spice in the flavour.
Pretty solid.
Bottle. Dark, clear reddish-orange with a frothy cream colored head. Aroma of toast, grass, and toffee. Tastes toasty, lightly sweet and fruity, and lightly bitter. Medium bodied and a little dry.
Bottle pour. The beer is a clear copper with a white head of foam. Sweet and toasty notes with a big of bite. Moderately sweet. Moreso than I would expect. Medium body and medium carbonation.
Pours a ruby-orange-amber with light tan head. Subtle custardy nose. Full, nearly heavy mouthfeel. Flavor profile is on the weak side. Custard is the dominant flavor.
Attractive deep ruby amber. Frothy beige head. Easy drinking but plenty of character. Smooth and balanced. Good one.
Clear amber in appearance. Aromas of caramel, and floral. Flavors of caramel and floral with a fairly high bitter aftertaste.

12 oz bottle received as a gift from my lovely wife. The pour is a brown copper golden with a small off white head that leaves behind minimal lace. The aroma is caramel nut malt and fresh grass. Hint of toasted bread present as well. The taste is clean and fresh caramel nut toasted malt, closing with the bright grass in the back. The palate is medium bodied, fine natural carbonation and the dry grass finish. Solid Oktoberfest.
Sweet and roasty, malty taste. Medium body. Reminds me of fall and football in Wisconsin.
Bottled. Medium amber brown pour. Lots of fresh malt and caramel. Really a nice example
Sweet. Caramel. Nutty. First Oktoberfest of the season and Im ready for some cooler weather please.

Amber brown with a modest off-white head and nice lace. Malt-forward aromas with earth, toast, raisin and brown sugar. Flavor is mostly malt sweetness with only a hint of bittering grassy hop. Medium body and carbonation, prickly mouthfeel and a lingering dark fruit sweetness in the finish. Better than all the pumpkin beers that were on display.

12oz bottle. Pours amber with a moderate off-white head. Aroma is malt - caramel, toffee, molasses. Taste is initially the same with spice, a light nuttiness, and a moderately bitter hop finish. Medium body. Moderate carbonation.

Poured hazy burnt sienna (Oh, how Ive missed that hue descriptor, as such!), with off-white head. Nose was caramel malt, molasses, light hops. Tasted caramelly, with supporting cast hops, and an earthy finish.
bottle. Deep amber with one finger head. Medium body with caramel and toffee malt. Mild nut notes. Light hops. Pretty solid oktoberfest style.

Aroma is of syrupy malts. Taste is sweet and malty. The residual after taste is actually more malt. very robust with a semi smokey finish. Turns out that it is actually quite dry for a big malty beer. Very refreshing in the face of all of the flavors of the Sculpin IPA.
On tap at Whole Foods Post Oak. Pours a clear copper with small off white head that lasts. The aroma is caramel, spice, pumpkin. Medium body, spice, pumpkin, caramel, light finish, very good.
Tap at GNBF. Poured dark amber, off white head. Aroma was malt, toffee. Taste is sweet, caramel, toffee, light spice.

12oz bottle. Pours a very deep orange brown with a nice head of tan cream with some larger bubbles mixed in. Aroma is very creamy malts, some earthy dough. Flavors bring forward the toasty grain and toffee. A touch of burnt notes. A bit of cleaning bitterness. A very nice marzen and perfect beer to create an appetite for fall weather.

Purchased at Bottles and Cans in Chicago, IL; enjoyed on Labor Day weekend on a gorgeous evening. Appearance is dark amber with a rich slightly off white head. Aroma is heavy on caramel malt, light lager yeast. Taste is pretty good, toasted malt, light toffee. Pretty standard for the style but its done well, wouldnt have expected otherwise from this place.

Bottle. Brown color. Rich, full malt flavor and aroma in this beer. Lager yeast aroma amd grain. Medi sweet, tons of malt flavor, and a dry finish. One of the best Octoberfests I have tried in a long time.
Slightly sweet toffee and caramel. Light palate and short finish, but a little fatiguing from the sweetness. Some other notes: hay, biscuit, honey.

Pour is a clear brown with a huge tan head. Aroma is a nice pleasant bready malt with some nuttiness. Flavor is again a malt to start then comes a sweet toffee and the alcohol makes a noticable appearance. This was just o.k. Nice toasted malt but this is a little bit boozy.
Pours a bright and deep orange color with a foamy white head. Notes of roasted nuts, caramel, soap, and gourds? Overall pretty solid with a semi-sweet mouthfeel.

Sure am disappointed by this. First clue was the predominantly brown color versus the copper. Then the aroma was kind of perfumey soap. Flavor was the best part, a bit toasty, malty, just enough carbonation to balance. Body was good too. Finish decent. Still, not my fav Okfest.
Bottle from World Market. Rich and roasty up front. Quite a bit of sweetness. This brew has a fairly thick mouthfeel. Some toasty malt flavors. Not much in the way of hops. Pretty full flavored.

Nice clear dark amber pour with small tan head that stays around. Aroma is the best part for me, with lots of caramel and bready malt goodness. Flavor is similar though a very slight metallic bitter comes out at the finish. A bit more carbonation than desired. Otherwise a very good easy-drinking fest.

Deep amber with a tall rocky off-white head.
Sweet aroma, molasses and toffee, 
The flavor is sweet on the front with some bitterness coming in at the back.
The aroma promised a bit more than the flavor delivered.

Pours a clear golden brown on tap with fluffy off-white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of mild malty sweetness, hint of earth. Taste follows, but bigger, nice mild sweetness with good earthy hop tones. Solid for the style.

On tap at Bearden Beer Market. Bronze, with a thin but dense beige head. Smells like sweet caramel and toffee and a bit of pumpernickel bread. Taste is more caramel and toffee, some maple, and a just a bit of woody hops in the finish.

Pint on tap. Darkish copper and clear with a film of foam. Nose is toffee, light cocoa and dried grass. Tastes the same with a bit of apple as well. A little roastier and drier than many in the style, but well balanced and has a smooth medium carbonation.
Aromas of toast, wet leaves, and marmalade. Taste is charred toast, caramel, honey, and sharp earthy hops.

(8-14-16) 12 oz bottle poured into Pilsner glass. BO date of July 17th. Deep burnt orange-hued amber color. Thin off-white head that dissipates quickly. Caramel and sweet cereal on the nose. Toffee, caramel, and toast all balanced harmoniously. Slightly dry/spicy finish.
Pours a half finger of head on a dark straw body. Aroma is grain, earth and lemon. Taste is caramel and mild lemon. Malty. Texture is thicker.

While its name conjures the psychological horror film by David Cronenberg, the beer itself makes you think of the "pure" examples of German Oktoberfests. Dark amber color with lots of suds. Caramel and bread aromas. Toffee and grain flavors. Hardly any hop bitterness. Pretty full-bodied. Why do so many great Oktoberfests come from California? Must be the old German brewing roots.

$2.10 bottle from Wine Warehouse. Pours an amber-brown with lots of bubbles and a small head. Aroma of brown leaves, peas, caramels. Flavor is not really one of my favorites, and I cant quite pinpoint it. Roasted malts, lightly sweet grasses, glue, bread.

Corn and caramel malt aroma. Not great, reminds me of a macrobrew Mexican lager. The appearance is great. See through light amber color with an off white head. Nice malty flavor, no hops at all. The caramel and toffee really shines in the aftertaste. Good slick palate, perfect amount of carbonation. This was pretty good other than the aroma.
Draft. Quinine, caramel malt, and hay aroma. Amber with giant head. Mildly sweet toffee malt and moderately bitter earthy quinine/hay flavor. Okay body. Kind of harsh for an Oktoberfest.

It pours dark amber with a beige head. The aroma has dark roasted roasty, molasses and lager roundness. It has a medium smooth body with mellow carbonation. The taste has roasted malt, brown sugar, dried bread and dry caramel. Pretty nice.

Rated on 8-09-2016. The appearance of this bottled beer after being poured is a medium sized fizzy beige head that mostly diminished, transparent copper body, fast rising carbonation observed, and no lacing. The aroma is malt, caramel, spicy, toffee, light hops, and bread. The flavor presents malt, caramel, toffee, spicy, bread, light hops, and a semi-dry finish. The mouthfeel is light-moderate carbonation and this beer is light-medium bodied. This is an easy drinking beer with a decent taste to it.

Bottle. Pours a clear, deep caramel, medium off-white head with decent retention. Nose is malt forward, caramel, dried fruit, toast. Mouth is medium bodied, mild malt sweetness, caramelly, dates, figs, raisins, toasted bread. Very nice. All thats missing is the schnitzel and weisswurst with some coarse grained mustard. Prost!
Bottle - cloudy brown colour, slim off-white head. Sweet fruity malty aroma. Similar in the taste, pretty cloying. Doesnt taste much like any Oktoberfest Ive ever had. Not great.
Draught at CBM Toranomon. Quite sweet and heavy, toffee and fruit cake, sweet finish. Quite a fail, they seemed out of their comfort zone on that one, better go back to your Sculpin guys.
Tap at Toranomon. Cloudy brown-orange, tall fine head. Nose of caramel, bread, lots of apple, and a little spicy hop. Sweet apple flavor, dried fruit, raisin. Spicy, caramel. No thanks.

Draft sampler at tailspin poured a mild orange with white head. Nice malty nose, some grass and some sweet and a touch of citrus. The flavor was malty but not over the top. Mild sweetness to it. Maybe middle of the road for this style but very drinkable.

Backlog rating. 33cl bottle at BD Shoreditch. It pours a clean goldenc olor with medium white head. Aroma os grains grass and straw. Taste is also dry with more grass, lemon bite and straw. Light bodied with good carbonation. Overall, ok for style
9/25/15. 12oz bottle from Warehouse in Albany, GA. Amber pour with a small khaki head. Light biscuit and toffee aroma. Malty flavor, doughy, biscuit, a hint of chocolate, toffee, caramel. Not bad.

Bottle shared at BDSB - London. Pours clear amber with a creamy, khaki head. Toasted bread in the nose, hints of cereal, brown sugar. Medium sweet flavor with notes of toffee, toasty bread, dried berries. Light to medium bodied with average carbonation. Sweet finish with crispy cereal, dry caramel, slight bitter earth. Tasty festbier.

Bottle at BD Sheps Bush. It pours clear dark copper with a small white head. The nose is earthy, brown bread, toasted grain, cereal, light spice and dull sweetness. The taste is firmly bitter, brown bread, cakey, toasted grain, spice, cereal, nut and light alcohol hit with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate, prickly carbonation. A simple malty affair. Fine, but far from exciting.
On tap @ the brewery. amber orange body, off white head. Bready caramel with lightly floral and vague fruit undertones.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Pours amber brown with tan head. Aroma is overwhelming dark figgy fruits. Flavor is light and fruity with not as much malt body as one might expect. The high level of carbonation seems to cut the the palate short but then lasting caramel lingers. Very good Marzen.

Beach Liquors FWB bottle. Nice clear bronze color with a tan head than settles into a film. Aroma is lager yeast and caramel malt. Flavor statrts a little weak but then settles nicely with some spice, light caramel sweetness and a hint of bitterness. Pleasant fall beer.
Amber color with an off white head. Aroma is a little sweet with notes of apple. Flavor is sweet a little nutty with very mild fruit. Finishes bittersweet and smooth.
Toasty malt aroma with a little underlying caramel. Bready, toasty malt flavor with almost no bitterness. A little caramel sweetness in the finish. Nothing special, but good nonetheless

Mahogany appearance with a large beige head and a fair amount of lacing. Sweet, malty aroma of toffee and dark fruit. Taste is a little edgier as spicy , floral hops add to the mix. Toasty malts maintain their grip, though, and the caramel provides sweetness in the aftertaste. Medium bodied with average carbonation and a short lived finish.

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. This beer is a clear dark reddish amber brew with a large thick off-white head. The aroma is full of malt. The taste is a smooth mix if malt and nut flavor that is very pleasing. Overall, a nice example of an Oktoberfest beer.

Dark malts, pumpernickel, earthy notes, a little molasses, and the most slightly spicy/peppery hops make a dark, alluring nose. Solid, almost vigorous carbonation livens a medium-to-thin body. The taste is malty bitter, with very residual sugary sweetness. The aftertaste is a bit spicy and toasty, leaning dry but not overly so. Not as intricate as it is just tasty.
Very solid oktoberfest. Nicely malty, slightly bitter, almost astringent finish, but nice nutty malt throughout.
Bottle. Decent beer. Grains, cereals, malts, perfumes, florals, more sweetness. Mostly clear. Brownish color. Thin off white head.
35 cl bottle @ home. Pours clear reddish amber with a white head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma and flavour are caramel, roasted malt, and spices - with a slightly sweet finish.
Bottle at home 2 weeks ago. Again the same.. The beer was good, the night was good. What more can I say.

12oz bottle in a tulip. Pours brown with an off-white head. Aroma of pale and caramel and lightly nutty malts, some toast, hints of hops, and some bread/dough. Flavor the same. Average texture. A decent beer, but not my favorite style.

Pours a nice dark amber color with minimal head retention and minimal to no lacing. Smells malty and slightly of hops. Tastes sweet and almost like a red, which fits the Oktoberfest profile. A decent beer, but I expected more from Ballast Point.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark Amber color with a reddish hue and topped by a small head of off white foam that quickly settles to a thin film. The aroma Is malt forward with notes of toasted bread, grains, and caramel malts to go with some nuts and balancing bitterness from the hops and traditional lager yeast. The flavor follows with the burnt caramel and toasted bread malt sweetness along with some grains, nuts, and balancing hop bitterness on the back end. The yeast is clean and crisp and rounds things out. Medium bodied and fairly smooth with balanced carbonation that leads a to clean and slightly bitter finish. Overall not bad for the style as it was very easy drinking, but maybe a touch sweet. This is just a style I cant really get into.

Nutty, putty, seedy, slightly toasty aroma which I liked. Good label, standard longneck. Darker than your average berfest. Aromatics come through to the flavor. A little toasty, faint cocoa, malty sweetness. Unusual and entertaining. This is a really sturdy brew without being sticky. Really enjoyed. ABC Liquors, Betton.

12iz bottle. No code date. Appearance: Deep reddish brown, clear, with minimal off white foam cap that disappears immediately. 
Aroma: Base of toasted malt with a definite sulfur aroma to the yeast. Hint of roast noticeable. 
Taste: High malt sweetness, with bready and toasty notes. A bit of caramel malt as well. Crisp bitterness and some noticeable sulfur on the swallow. 
Mouthfeel: Medium body with a light to moderate bitterness. Overall feel is a bit thin. 
Finish: Some breadiness there after the swallow, but leans toward the bitter side 
Overall: Lacking the dominant bready/toasty malt of other marzens, somewhat one dimensional flavor and overly sweet, and a noticeable sulfur aroma. Was looking forward to trying a lager from Ballast Point. This needs a lot of work.

Bottle. Head is initially small, frothy, off-white to light brown, mostly/fully diminishing. Body is dark amber. Aroma is moderately malty (scorched caramel, toasted grain, nuts), lightly hoppy (apricot). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately to heavily bitter. Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

A poor head and mouthfeel hurt this one a bit, but honestly the aroma is pretty limited and burnt-caramel heavy. The flavor balance is ok but pretty aggressively bitter. A bit of a rough-edged sketch of a beer that needs polishing.

(Bottle). Earthy brown complexion with quickly diminishing head. Mellow and mildly malty traditional flavor Very smooth pallet and easy to session. Probably one of the better Oktoberfest/Marzen Ive had in a long time. Ballast Point proves it can do more than hoppy. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: SEP 15, 2016 Easy drinking oktoberfest...sweet caramel and malty goodness...real easy sipper...i would drink this one again.

Bottle from BottleDog, Edinburgh. Clear amber/brown body with a medium beige head. Steady carbonation. Light lacing. Aroma of caramel, lightly roasted malt and earth. Flavour of stewed tea, peppery hops and brown sugar. Thin to medium body with an oily texture. Soft fizz. Sweet and well rounded.

Pours a clean, but soft, copper with ruby tints and two fingers of tan head. Nose and flavor dont match what I come to expect from an Oktoberfest/Marzen. Lots of sweet caramel malt and dark fruit/raisins. Almost cloyingly sweet in the flavor with a lightly grainy character and some alcoholic heat. Mostly sweet and fruity in the nose with a light acrid quality and hints of booze. Unbalanced and not very good.

Nice looking dark brown with read hues. Head goes quick but adds a soft mouthfeel. Good malt upfront with an odd almost bitter hop finish. Seems less like an Oktoberfest and more like a brown. A little molasses, toffee, a late roasted malt flavor somewhere between coffee and earthy chocolate are split by a quick hit of hops. Seems just a touch over bitter. Earthiness may be from hops at second sip. Bitter lingers for a few seconds. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a reddish-copper with little to no head. Aroma is very grassy. Flavor is also quite grassy, with some malt underneath. Not terrible.
Bottle at home. Pours deep amber, nose is toffee, malty, cereal, taste is sweet, grainy, toffee.

Tallahassee, Fl - ABC Fine Wine & Spirits - Betton Hills - 12 oz bottle. Dark copper pour, little to no head. Aroma has some toffee accents, some ripening vegetable funkiness. Flavor has some caramel sweetness, a bit of subtle pumpkin pie spiciness, some ripening vegetables. Decently thick mouthfeel.
Pours Amber With a thin head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of malt but extra sweet. Flavor is sweet malt with a bit of funky aftertaste.
Bottle at home. Reddish amber pour with a smaller head. Sweet toffee, malt, hint of tea - this is pretty darn good in its style.
あまくてすっ
Nice marzen. Copper colored. Brown sugar, malt, tea, earth. Pretty sweet, and a tad watery, but overall enjoyable.

12 ounce bottle. Dark Amber color. Small beige head. Sweet malt aroma has hints of melon and brewed tea. Flavor is toasted malt with toffee notes. Slightly bittersweet with a touch of brown sugar and raisins and baked apples. Different than most Marzenbier beers.

Pours a clear dark copper body with thin layer of tan head. Nutty, earthy malt aroma with wafts of caramel and brown sugar. Robust malt taste of sweet toffee, slight roasted flavors, and hints of dark fruit. A touch of bitter dryness on the finish. Pleasant and drinkable beer.
Bottle from Halls Liquor. Pours a deep ruby red with w thin off white head. Flavor and aroma are spot on for an octoberfest but its a little too watery with not enough malt. Cheers!

Ballast Point is quickly becoming one of my favorite breweries. Up until recently, theyve seemed incapable of error. But with Dead Ringer, their entry into the Oktoberfest/Marzen style, they finally dropped the ball. When my friends and I reviewed this in a blind taste test last month it was awful. This particular bottle is much better than that one, though its still not that good. Its possible something may have happened to this beer in transit to my area, but whatever the case may be, its just a disappointing experience.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a shaker glass. It was bottled on 8/4/15 and cost $3.05 ($0.25 per ounce).

Appearance: Pretty copper/mahogany hue; fairly clear with some carbonation visible. Pours to a small, off-white, soapy head which nearly completely dissipates and leaves no lacing.

Smell: Fairly typical dark lager aroma, but a strong presence of something off. A bit of a cranberry scented candle (and I dont mean that as a compliment). More mild than bad, but far from good.

Taste: Going into this beer, I prepared for the worst and hoped for the best. Its strange when you review a beer you had a bad experience with. I was hoping it was just the bottle last time, but it doesnt appear to have been an isolated incident. Theres definitely a familiar Marzen character here with the presence of slightly sweet darker malt and just a hint of fruity flavor (maybe some toffee, too). Unfortunately, its completely obscured by a sour tanginess to the palette. Much like the nose, theres a presence akin to cranberry in here: tart and a little astringent. No hop character that I can detect. The flavor seems to worsen as it warms. I dont know what the deal is with this beer, but I do not like it.

Drinkability: It always surprises me when a bad beer is nominally high in alcohol. Ballast Point Dead Ringer is 6% ABV, which isnt unusual for the style. That being said, it does not deliver what I expect in a beer with that potency. The mouthfeel is tepid, a bit oily, and a little warming. It finishes clean, but it is not refreshing at all. Theres no challenge to drink this, but theres no enjoyment, either.

RATING: 3/10

Having lived in Germany, I learned quickly to appreciate Marzens. Ballast Points Dead Ringer is as close as I have come to a real German Style Marzen which become so plentiful in Deutschland this time of year. Sure it is no Vetter (should you ever find your self in Heidelberg, Vetter is easily found in the Altstadt).But, for an American Ocktoberfest, Dead Ringer hands down blows away every other one I have tried this year. I wish I could describe it in the terms normally associated with beer, yet after each sip I find myself back on the banks of the Neckar in a dream state I never wish to leave. (Biased, why yes.)
12 oz bottle. Red brown and hazy with a decent sized khaki head. Aroma is of toast, bread dough, leaves, toffee, and caramel. Taste is of toffee, woody herbal hops, malt, toast, walnuts, and caramel.
Sweet malt, tea, dried leaves aroma, not strong. Cloudy, ruby brown, thin tan head. Malt, dried leaves. Bitter finish. Medium body, moderate carbonation.

On tap at Whole Foods Market  Chandler. A typical märzen nose with cloying caramel and musty cereal grain, along with a rotting vegetal tone and a touch of toffee. Pours semi-murky dark mahogany. The taste features an odd mix of prominent woody notes and sweet caramel. A decent earthy hop bitterness (a bit more than called for in the style). Medium body leaning toward heavy; Oily mouthfeel; bitter woody finish that leaves an unpleasant aftertaste reminiscent of old spices well past their best-by date. The unfortunate finish really hurts my impression of an already mediocre Oktoberfest-style brew.
Bottle pours copper brown with a thin pale head. Caramel and biscuit aroma. Taste is similar. Sweetness gets a little cloying by the end of the glass.

A bit rough around the edges, with a burnt caramel malt flavors that shows elements of sanguine and iron, finishing with a stale bread aftertaste. Kind of all over the place and way too dark/heavy for this style.

12oz bottle poured into pint glass. The aroma is a roasted grain and cooked caramel blend with a light nuts, malty, and earthy undertone. The beer is a clear caramel brown with a tan, fizzy, unstable head that has no retention or lace. The taste is a medium high sweet and medium light bitter blend. The beer is oily and smooth with a fizzy carbonation and a medium full body with roasted flavors, some earthy tones, and caramel, with a touch of citrus fruit. The roasted finish is fresh and clean with a mild pine and mild citrus zip and ends with a grainy feel that leaves an aftertaste of toffee and nuts.
Heavy sweet caramel malts, very round mouthfeel, almost a little too "big" and sweet. Meh.
Probably exactly how a marzen should be. Prawn, toasty malts. Slightly boozy. Crisp hop finish without much residual sweetness.

Pours a clear coppery color with off-white head. Caramel malt, toffee, biscuit, and a light toast on the nose; follows onto the palate. Medium to full bodied, smooth mouthfeel. Finishes with toffee and bread.

The aroma on this is really unusual. Its got some nice woody notes but also a strange estery smell thats not unpleasant, just unusual. Slightly hazy deep hazelnut brown with a slightly ruddy tinge and a low lying head. That estery aroma follows into the taste along with a nutty malt flavor. Theres a bit of a bite from the alcohol which probably only seems that way due to the lower bitterness of the beer. Lots of sweet toffee and caramel here with a creamy body that gives it a bit of a marshmallow feel. Finishes sweet and dry with a nice woody aftertaste. Im not sure Id call this a dead ringer for an Oktoberfest, but its got the right feel and its a tasty brew regardless.

Beautiful dark chestnut brown with a very noisy tan head that fades fast to a coating and then nothing. Aroma is malty lightly roasted grains. Active in the mouth with a taste that balances rich roasted malts and some toffee sweetness with a jolt of noble hop bitterness. A really excellent Fest beer. You can taste a classic lager base and also enjoy the aging and additional malts that make this a marzen.

This was poured into a mug.
The appearance was a hazy burnt caramel color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated nicely. Lacing slides into the beer.
The smell has a rich caramel maltiness with a light leafy earthiness underneath. Nuttiness is light.
The taste was mainly malt sweet through the caramel flavors. Earthiness and nuts taste dry but show a light presence.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionable feel to it. Carbonation feels right as an Oktoberfest.
Overall, its a good Oktoberfest, theres nothing wrong with it.

Average at best. Aroma isn't really there and appearance is a dull copper brown. There are better choices out there

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours clear, bubbly sienna with an effervescent head that says hello and then takes off. Aroma is not strong, but tempts with fresh malt and caramel tones. Flavor is bolder, with stronger caramel presence as well as fruity and hoppy hints. Body is average, and fizz is barely present; but finish is pleasing. I was going to save this for Oktoberfest, then remembered that Germany is several hours ahead of Atlanta - so its officially on, albeit just by the calendar.

12 oz. bottle. Pours brown amber with a nice tight foamy beige head that fades. Smells of sweet grain roasted malt dough bread. Taste is warm baked doughy bread slightly sweet and a dulled bitter finish. Palate is thin crisp and slightly dry finish. I dig it.

Pours cloudy brown with reddish tint. Nose is malt, brown sugar, caramelized banana. Tastes of toffee, caramel, toast and biscuit. Sweet at first but dry, lightly hopped finish. Very nice, great for the style.

Pours a clear dark amber with a dark ruby cast. Below normal head volume, lacing and retention.

The nose is heavy on the malt with biscuit, cracker and caramel elements. As it warms, toffee appears underneath along with a nice burst of floral hops with a distinct apple aroma.

Medium body with a creamy texture. Perfect carbonation with a nice effervescent burst in the middle and a rollicking finely bubbled prickly finish.

The flavor profile is unusual for a marzen. It is more intense and has a bit more toasted grain huskiness and hops than you usually encounter. It begins with a blend of grainy malt flavor coupled with a toasted nut element. The middle brings a light bitterness over caramel/toffee that attains a subtle sweetness to balance. The finish has a subtle apple flavor and a lingering aftertaste that is slightly medicinal.

Pours chestnut brown with a thin tan head, moderate retention. Aromas of caramel, toast, earth. Medium-light body, smooth and crisp. Medium sweet, medium bitter finish. A detectable but not unpleasant amount of minerals. Well balanced and drinkable.

Pours deep brown color, the head fades away quickly. The aroma is caramel, apple butter, some spice. The flavor is rich and a little too sweet for me. Molasses, scotch notes, clean finish. It isnt bad, but not my style.

12 oz bottle poured into a lager glass.

Appearance: Dark reddish-brown body topped by a small head that soon reduces to a thin, partial coat. 

Aroma: Surprisingly hoppy; more hoppy than malty. Hints of toffee and biscuits and some off-notes. 

Taste: Largely follows the aroma. Mild+ bitterness. 

Feel: Moderate carbonation, medium body.

Overall: This is a very hoppy and earthy Marzen thats also rather bitter for style. Not bad but off style and a rare miss from Ballast Point.  Bad batch or bottle?

Bottle. Pours a walnut brown color with white head. Toast, malty, slight toffee aromas. Slick, toast, biscuit, malty, slight toffee flavors. Best oktoberfest of the 6 American versions I tried this weekend.

12oz bottle. Pours rusty brown with a small off white head. Aroma is of grass, hops, malt, and candy. The aroma is different, thats for sure. Taste is of grassy hops, sugar, those hard candies your grandmother always had, and toasty malt. Lingering grassy sugar taste. Tastes pretty Damn good. Mouthfeel is light and very carbonated. Body is light and drinks easy. Tasty. I liked it.

Chestnut brown pour with almost no head. Aroma of nuts and toast. Malty and sweet with a nuttiness that is very pronounced. Caramel malts and toasted notes are also prevalent. I was worried it was flat on the pour, but there was a decent level of carbonation on the tongue. Pretty good effort of a style that is admittedly not my favorite.

On tap, poured a dark copper almost brown hue w/ rich off white creamy head and thick lacing. Moderate malty aroma. Initial flavor is light to moderate sweet w/ a moderate bitter finish of shirt duration. Tastes are caramel, dark toast, hint of cocoa, and hint of lime. Medium bodied and creamy mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle - clear amber pour - nose of dough, dark fruit (raisin), caramel, innocuous spiciness - a bit hefty and not as clean as youd expect in the style - medium to full body - fairly sweet - dough, toasty malt, spiciness, dark fruit, dark bread - overall, again, a little hefty and lacking the expected cleanliness, but its still decently enjoyable.
Pours amber with a small tan head that quickly dissipated. Aroma is toast, caramel and nutty. Taste is sweet with traces of bitterness. Medium bodied with a sticky finish.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2015 Tasting this blind has lowered my opinion of it considerably--not that I was in love w/ it to begin w/. This was one of the worst of over thirty Oktoberfests we tried. Its got loads of acetone, apples and stressed yeast weirdness in the nose--almost malt liquor-y.  It tastes decent considering, malty and a bit on the sweet side. I think of Ballast Point as being typically a good technical brewery but this is all kinds of wrong. 

Original (2.7):This one is close but its not quite on point. Its headless and cloudy brown. Its nose initially seems to have a fresh caramel malt thing going on but the sweetness when you taste it seems to bring out some cooked veggie weirdness and that brings things down a notch. This is full bodied and just a bit syrupy w/ prickly carbonation. My initial impression of this was quite favorable but as I dig in Im just finding more I dont like. I could probably drink this just fine if I wasnt paying attention but sitting here and writing this review, its not really working for me.
Shared a couple bottles with friends. lots of toasted malts as expected from the style. sweet and malty throughout. Not a bad representation. Love the label.

On tap at The Mayor of Old Town. Clear light brown appearance with a beige ring of head. The aroma has toasted grain and a slight off-note with a hint of alcohol. The flavor is better, bread, light chocolate and a smooth, clean malt flavor. Light earthy bitterness balanced by mild sweetness, notes of caramel and toffee. Pretty solid rendition overall.

Sampled on draft at 3R6P this beer poured a black color with orange highlights and a medium sized fluffy beige head that lingered and left a bit of lacing. The aroma was faint toasty malts with a touch of wood and cherry. The flavor was toasty, malted milk, vanilla, cola, a hint of dark fruits and a medicinal presence underneath. Medium length cola, dark fruit and medicine finish. Medium body. Meh.
bottled, copper orange color with dirty tan head, good caramel fruit note aroma, flavor is tasty malty caramel, squash, gourd, nice finish

12 oz bottle, cool label, date code 15216. Dark ruby color with a white head. First thing I get on the nose is acetaldehyde green apple unfortunately, with some toasty maltiness. Flavor is more squashy bad stuff and some toasty, biscuity maltiness. Total bummer, man. Almost had to pour it out.
Bottle. Pours amber with an off white head. Toasted and lightly sweet malts, some bready notes, mild earthy bitterness, and a clean balanced finish. Chuggable.

12oz bottle. Deeper than expected burgundy-brown body. The aroma isnt true to style or enjoyable, some chocolate amber, unenjoyable fruity tones. The amber and other specialty malts really dominate, no crisp hop balance. Surprisingly missing the mark. Not that good in general, really unimpressive for the style.

12oz bottle. Brown pour with little foam. Nose is malty with a strange green like aroma. The Taste is heavy on the caramels and toffee making it overly sweet, missing the balance of the hops. Again Im still picking up a strange taste in the middle of unripe green leaf like flavors. Didnt care for this one.
Dark copper body, thin light tan head, spotty lacing. Super sweet caramel, mild toast and nuttiness. Medium to full bodied, overly sweet, soft carbonation. Not particularly polished.

Cloudy deep copper with a thin foamy ivory head. Big spice up front on the nose with a touch of clove, and slightly smokey marzen lager malts. Different from conventional style guidelines and I love it! Lovely autumnal flavors of marzen lagery biscuity malts, slight smokiness, dried leaves, clove, and a kiss of sweet maple on the biscuity finish. Really nice.
330ml bottle at Brew on Quay Ak poured copper brown & frothy the aroma is mainly caramel malt the taste is similar quality creamy smooth & lightly hopped enjoyed

12oz bottle from Xroads. Poured a murky deep red/amber body with a full foamy creamy head. Aroma is blah, lots of dusty grains, bad caramel, way bad wort, bad molasses. Flavor sadly is basically the same with a touch of grassy hops and some super wet melting red licorice. Blah overall.
12oz bottle to mini dimple. Definitely leans to the American style. Sweet and malty. Caramel.

12 oz bottle pours a light brown color with an off white head. Aromas of malt, caramel, toffee. Light bodied a nice fall beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a rich caramel color with an off white head. Sweet malt, caramel, toffee biscuit, toast and earthy hop aroma and flavors. Medium full body and moderate carbonation. Toast, sweet malt and caramel finish. Good flavor but not the most drinkable Märzen.

12oz bottle pours with a clear deep copper to amber colored body that supports a tan head of foam. The aroma offers up various malt notes that are caramel, molasses and biscuit mixing with fruity esters like peach and raisin and then a mild spicy hop sensation. The taste delivers smooth caramel malts, biscuit malts and a touch of molasses and then sweetened a tad by mild peach and pear and plum like fruity esters. This manages to stay well away from becoming too sweet thanks to the less than sweet malt additions and the modest degree of spicy to slightly pine to faintly floral hop notes. I love the balance here.

Appearance: deep clear auburn, with ruby highlights and two fingers of creamy, frothy, near white head that slowly shrinks to a thin cap, leaving good lacing.  Aroma: thick nose full of caramel, leather, toffee, brown sugar, and earth. Taste: light molasses, lots of brown bread, caramel, toffee, a bit of toasted nuts and treacle.  Finish: chewy and slightly slick, with just a hint of earthy hops. Notes: 	Clearly an excellent beer. Almost too amped up for the style; the palate was overly full. I like my marzens to have just a hint of a bite at the back end to cleanse the palate, and this seemed almost on the border of a thick brown ale. Needed just a little more zip in the palate, but the flavor was good, as was the aroma. Very pretty to look at as well. Bottle from Total Wine & More in Alexandria, Virginia.

caramel, toast, grass, basement aromas, earthy, amber, clear, frothy, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, astringent, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, astringent.

I am reluctant to post this review, because I am not wont to issue overly negative responses, especially when it comes to a brewery like Ballast Point which I greatly admire, and Im willing to accept that I may have received a bad bottle. However, I drew my sample from some cases that I just received in my store this week. With that stipulation, I have to say in all honesty that this is a terrible beer, having no discernable relationship to traditional German Oktoberfest marzens. My negative reaction starts with the off-putting aroma of caramelized plastic. The unpleasantness continues on the palate with astringently bitter caramelized malt flavors that persist on the finish. There is no rounded breadiness that one expects from the style. At the risk of being redundant, this beer is an unpleasant drinking experience and very disappointing, considering the source. As I said, I will be happy to be contradicted and told that I simply have received a bad bottle. I hope that is the case.
This to sweet or heavy, clean and a nice American interpretation.poured a translucent orange color with a white head. Aroma was of grass, toasted caramel, and a bit nutty. Flavor similar, not

Bottle. Pours out a nice darker orange/amber with a small white head. Aroma is of lots of caramel, bread, pastry dough and some light grassy bitterness. Taste is clean, caramel, grains, doughy bread, very little grassy bitterness. Spot on for the style and pretty tasty for a style I usually am just met on.
Pretty nice example of the style of just a touch hoppier. Nice rich malt and bready backbone throughout.
Smells like fall. Pours a deep reddish brown. Aroma is full of malty caramel notes. Easy finish...good stuff.

Draught @ Ballast Point Brewing Co (Little Italy), San Diego, CA. Pours a copper colour with a small foamy head. Aroma of bready malts, a bit of sweetness and hay. Flavour is surprisingly rich with toasted malts, bread and grassy bitterness. Flavour is also quite sweet for this style. Medium bodied. A bit less sweetness and this would rock.

Draught @ Ballast Point, San Diego. Aroma is a bit musty with gooseberry bush leaves and some malt. Flavour has berries, some grapefruity hops and bush leaves. Also dunkel-like roasted malt. Nothing special.

Draught @ Ballast Point Little Italy, San Diego, CA 

Pours dark copper orange with a small head. Aroma of malts, bready notes, hints of berries, caramel and toffee. Taste is smooth, malty and slightly sweet with hints of caramel, toffee and bread. Finish is smooth and malty with some hints of caramel and toffee. Decent.

Tap @ Ballast Point, San Diego.
Pours clear amber color with a small head. Malty aroma, gains and faint caramel notes, faint hay. Malts and some faint berry notes on the flavor, hay and grains. Good balance.
3314

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2015 Bottle. Lightly hazed dark amber with a short tan head. Aroma is malty, estery, and hoppy with notes of marzipan, grapefruit, orange, maraschino cherry, plum, licorice, perfume. Medium bodied, moderately sweet with matched bitterness, crisp and snappy in the mouth, with dominant notes of caramel malt, orange zest, red apples, various other fruits. Finishes with a decent grip of bitterness, caramelized malt, ale-like fruity esters. A decent attempt but pretty far from traditional.

Keg at Sedona Charlottesville. Clear copper, large foamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, mild berries and banana. The taste is caramel, toffee, mild cherries. Medium bodied, low carbonation.

12 oz. bottle. It pours a rather dark orange/copper color with a disappearing foamy creamsickle colored head. The aroma is a bit weird with a green, leafy herbal thing going on behind some toasted malt. Lightly sweet malt syrup as well with hints of metal. Not the most pleasant aroma, but not horrible. The flavor is kinda the same. Strong green, leafy hop flavor and bitterness with some sweet brown sugar and toasted malt. Not very rich or full on the palate. It pretty much dies in the finish other than the stronger than normal bitterness for the style. The carbonation is also a bit low. Wasnt a big fan of this one.
Bottle. Reddish amber in color with tan head. Toffee and caramel flavor. Semi- sweet taste.
Nice Marzen style beer. Slight toasted flavor that throws me off. Would drink again!

Bottle. Sweet caramel and toffee malt aroma with toasted malt and nutty notes. Pours caramel colored with a thin white head with poor retention and minimal lacing. Starts with sweet caramel and toffee flavors with a light, drinkable body. Finishes smooth with light notes of nuttiness and toast with the overall sweetness of the beer clinging to the palate. Solid beer, but I'm not sure I'd call it an Oktoberfest.
Sample at Dominion Wine and Beer. Pours a clearing cola with an off white head. Nutty nose. Flavors of malt roast.

More hop forward than I usually find an Oktoberfest to be but more sweet than anything. Caramel, toffee, malty goodness. Good beer just not in September. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared 12 oz. bottle poured to snifters, showing a clear, copper color, with a modest layer of off white head foam that diminished quickly to a light film, and spots of lacing. The nose was light grain, with some toast & nuttiness, and just a touch of caramel sweetness. Light bodied, with soft carbonation, the taste offered some modest bitterness, and a dry finish. Suits the summer, but not a lot of hutzpah for a style that I heartily embrace every fall.

Deep copper. Nose of big toasted malt, light caramel, and orange. Flavor is sweet orange and toasted malt with a medium plus herbal bitterness that hangs on. Lightly dry in the finish. One of the better Oktoberfests Ive had in awhile.

Originally rated on 10/17/14. Deep dark amber with brownish tinges, the cap recedes quickly leaving a thin off white ring that dosent leave any lace. Usual aromas of toasted malts, some nuttiness and toffee. Flavor is much the same,with the toasted nuttines. Overall it is a step above other beers of the same style if only because of the balance, not weak or over the top. Enjoyable and easy to drink.
(Draught) Pours an amber-brown body with a medium beige head. Aroma of roasted grain, toffee, caramel, florals, and bread. Flavor of roasted grain, toffee, earth, and caramel.

From the 650 ml. bottle stamped DP-12-14272. A bit past Oktoberfest season but I just found it. It is an attractive medium to dark amber-mahogany color with a big, lingering mocha head. Lacing. The aroma is alive with caramel and other sweet, roasty malts. Yeast. No hops. Medium body but smooth and delicate. Rich roasted malt taste and enough hops in the picture just to balance it out and help it end on the dry side.

Deep mahogany pour w/ a thin tan head & little lacing. The aroma contains so caramel & toffee notes. The taste also is dominated by the caramel & toffee w/ a dry bitterness in the finish. Im not big on Oktoberfests & this one isnt an exception!
Appearance is pretty dark for an Oktoberfest, aroma is earthy malts, fruit and slightly perfumed. The flavor is caramel, toffee, mild/medium sweetness, fruit and a dryish/tart finish.

From a bottle from the Old Grove brewery. Pours nut brown with a fizzy off white head. Tastes very malty, nutty, roasted. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like roasted malt, toasted grains, nutty.

Bottle. Pours clear dark copper with creamy beige head. Aroma is bready and toasted malts, some caramel, some dark fruit notes, and faint lager yeast esters. Flavor is toasted malt base, faint sweetness, faint dark fruits, and light hops. Light/medium body and medium carbonation.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a thin layer of off white head. Aroma and taste of bready malts, caramel, and spices.

Location: 22 oz bottle from State Line, 12/21/14


Aroma: It has a clean, sweet, malty aroma, with some caramel, toasted pumpernickel, and spice

Appearance: A darker orange/red/brown color, clear in the glass, with a clean, sheeting beige head

Flavor: The taste is clean and sweet as well, malty and bready, spice, and a light bitterness

Palate: The body is medium, it has a very smooth, creamy mouthfeel, with a soft carbonation

Overall Impression: 
This one is very solid for what it is trying to be.  I dont tend to love this style, but I can appreciate this one.  Well made, nice mouthfeel.

18 Dec 2014, bottle. light amber/brown, clear, no bubbles. nose is sweet whole grain bread, faint pine hops, caramel. med body and mildly fizzy. dark toast, sweet wort, faint pine hops, with a fainter smoky sausage taste. ok.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2016 Bottle from Chucks 11/28/14 

Glowing tan/brown pour with a nice rich head. Pretty. Caramel and bready aroma, some yeast. Caramel flavors, a rye-like snap. Flavors more intense than I recall from other examples of the style. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

Revisit bottle 8/30/16

I may have gone a bit high here with my previous rating. Deep brown with red highlights. Powerful malts up front, pretty sweet, reminding me of celebrator for some reason. The intense sweetness and dearth of hops makes it not nearly as drinkable as the SN Oktoberfest 2016 that preceded it. Id go more like 7/3/7/3/13=3.3. Splitting the difference.

650ml bottle. Pretty dark color for an oktoberfest, especially the tan head.Aroma is very "American" very sharp and almost citrusy, potpurri, water but not minerally, some sweet toffee. Flavor is sweet, lots of candy bon bon flavors, the finish has some dry noble hoppiness though. Some nuts and dark fruits. Its kinda all over the place.

Poured from bomber into a snifter. Pours a dark amber color with a small creamy tan head. Aroma consists of roasted malt, caramel, nuts, and toffee. Taste is much the same with a small amount of bitterness at the end. Medium bodied beer with a moderate amount of carbonation and a sticky mouth feel. Nice beer for the style and has a decent price

[ Keg ][ 4oz ][ Ballast Point Little Italy ][ $1.50-2 ][ Stemmed Tulip Flute ][ 11.6.14 ]
>> Deep amber pour, brilliant clarity. Good off white foam. Fresh dark bread, lemon nose. Taste is nice toffee, buttery rich malt, thick breadiness. Very good Oktoberfest. Rich, dark color, nicely bitter, not sweet. Pretty impressive.

Crystal clear brown with a small pale head. Aroma is caramel, malt, dates. Light bodied, slightly malty on the palate with a balancing light bitterness, slightly metallic finish. Taste is burnt sugar, malt, dates.

Dark caramel taste. Tasted this at an octoberfest beer tasting and it was good, heavier than traditional Octoberfest beers.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours deep mahogany into a shaker. Mocha head with medium retention recedes leaving spot lacing to skim surface. Dark caramel and candy corn aromas. Dry with sweet toffee and slight smoke upfront turning to mild bitter earth in the lasting finish.

Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer pours a very deep copper color with a one finger head of a tan colored foam. The head fades relatively quickly leaving a light level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma of the beer is heaviest of a sweeter smell of caramel and toffee with some nice big aromas of a roasted malt smell. Along with these smells comes some smells of some light spice of cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice with a little bit of dark fruit and nut.

 Taste  The taste begins with a caramel and toffee sweetened flavor with a big presence of a roasted malt taste. Along with these tastes are some toast and a decent spice flavor of nutmeg and allspice. A little bit of apple, comes soon after the initial tastes, with it only fading later as the taste advances. The spice seems to, all the while, get stronger, while the roastedness remains constant throughout. More spice and a little bit of graininess and a slight bit more toffee and caramel come at the very end, leaving a rather highly spiced and somewhat harsher roasted flavor to linger on the tongue.


 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the average side in terms of thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is on the average side. For the style the two are rather appropriate, but overall the feel is nothing all that special.

 Overall  A decent Oktoberfest, but a little too spicy for my taste. If looking for something with a nice roast and spice flavor then this is a good one, but if looking for something with a bit more smoothness, then this may not be your first choice.

22 oz. bottle. Dark, unclear mahogany color with slow fading head. Aroma is aged toffee and caramel malts. Stale lager yeast and toasted grain. 
Flavor is a display of the traditional style guidelines, older malt flavor of caramel and biscuit. Solid toasted grain body with a lager yeast flavor in the backend. Body is much fuller than the typical standard. Light spiciness toward the finish. Overall, it really is much more hearty then I was expecting, nice.

Thin white head. Very dark Amber color. Very malty nose of cereal, grains and a touch of apricot. The body has nice bready and caramel flavor. Medium body. Low hop character. Comes across very authentic and not a west coast hop bomb of a German styled beer. Perhaps a bit too high abv, drinks more like 6.5%, but take this down to 5.5% and you have a real winner. Good stuff.

22oz bottle. Medium beige head atop clear copper body. Aroma is moderately sweet, bread, some spicy, light caramel, earthy. Taste is moderately sweet, bread, some spicy, light earthy. Light-medium body, light stickiness.
Bottle. Mahogany with a thin white head. Aroma is caramel, toast and spice. Taste adds a touch of almond and apple. Medium sticky mouthfeel. Solid.
Bottle. Very dark amber. Toasted grains, caramel and toffee, sweet rich malts. Medium body with average carb. Very toasty. Pretty good.

Poured from bomber. Pours brown with amber tint and a tan head. Toasted Malt, Biscuty, herbal, yeast aroma. Sweet toasted caramel malt start with brown sugar and toffee. Biscuty notes and finishing with a herbal spicy yeastiness and slight hopiness. Nice rich maltiness in this one.
Darker reddish amber, moderate head, decent lace/retention. Aroma is toast, caramel, light grass. Medium bodied, flavors match aroma, somewhat sweet. Pretty straightforward but well put together.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors. It pours a light reddish brown color with a nice light tan head. Notes of toasted malt and light caramel in the nose. More of the same on the palate with a touch of sweetness and a light fruitiness. Nice crisp finish. A very nice example of the style.

22 ounce bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe. The aroma has some toast and a little roast with biscuit notes. Some metallic lager hints are also present. A little floral, too. Transparent amber body with a medium, creamy, light tan head present. Starts with a nice, toffee-like sweetness. Becomes nutty in the middle with a good roastiness and toastiness. Finishes dry, and lightly bitter with some floral character. This has a really nice body and mouthfeel. Really solid stuff.
Rich, toasted brown color. The head loots like latte foam, white and tan. Clean, brisk malt aroma. Flavor is all malt with a ln earthy finish. Good as malt goes.

Copper brown in color... Aroma of nutty malts, caramel, toffee... Flavor is very nutty, notes of spices, toasted malts, pilsner hops on finish... Solid beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

650 ml bottle. Pours a roan brown color that has red highlights when held to the light. The head is beige with spotty lacing and very good retention. The aroma is medium in strength with roasted barley, bitter walnuts, and sweet pitted fruits. The taste is very old school Oktoberfest with toffee, caramel, walnuts and hazelnuts. The palate was just a bit thinner than I prefer and the carbonation was soft. Finished short and clean. Overall: This is probably the best lager Ive had all year-- going to drink a ton of it this fall fer sure. Im really digging this one, but thats probably because we get so few good lagers here.

A little roast comes into this initially. So much that I initially thought I was drinking the wrong beer, especially with the darker colour. Pours clear maroon with ok head and lacing. Some of that trashy marzen aroma with some caramelized malt. Finishes with light sweetness. Definitely good for style, even if its stretching the category a little. Tap at Churchkey.

Growler fill at Home Brew Mart. Pours thickly dark amber (light ruby-brown?) with ample foamy body and lacing on glass. Aromas are lightly of brownish malts, lots of caramel and toastiness here, with just a touch of roasty and acidic apple characters... Taste is pleasantly mixed between solid malt backbone, caramel, biscuit, apple cider, and a light-bodied quaffability that I personally really appreciate. Some more spices come through in the palate, cinnamon and something more that I cant place. Finish is clean and yummy. Really perplexed why this doesnt rate higher, but that could be entirely because I am not well versed enough in the style. Bottom line: I like it.

Tap at Capitol Beer in Sacramento, CA. Pours dark ruddy copper with a creamy beige head. Med body. Aroma of light roast malt and spice. Flavor is spicy, darkish malt. Sweet, but not desperately so. Quite tasty, tho hardly bitter in the finish.

On tap at the hopping pig in San Diego and something is clearly wrong with the beer. Looks like a marzen but smells and tastes like raspberries. Berry is the predominant aroma. The flavor has is sweet with toffee nuttiness and then full on raspberry notes. Medium bodied, average carbonation. I liked the beer but from a standpoint of a marzen not so much. I have a hard time believing Ballast Point would put this out there, there must have been something wrong with the beer or somebody pulled a switcheroo and mislabeled the tap. Who knows Ill have to try this again somewhere else to compare.
On tap at brewery. Not too shabby, caramel and toffee notes with a strong malt presence. Pours a very clear ruby red.

Amber pour with a white head. Simple and sweet aroma. Nose of caramel, toffee, and toasted bread. A lot of fruity esters, particularly pear, along with yeast and some floral hops. Light spice notes, too. The flavor is fairly sweet and malty. Caramel, toffee, and toast, as with the aroma. Nice fruity ester profile, floral hops, yeast, spice, and a hint of grass.

On tap @ Home Brew Mart: Poured a dark burnt orange almost mahogany in hue with a frothy layer of foam head. Aroma is subtle with only a touch of caramel malts. The flavor is similar to a Scotch ale but does delivery a deep toffee/caramel malt profile that doesnt stray far from true German Marzens.

Tap at South Beach Bar and Grill in OB. Clear reddish brown with a one finger beige head, down to a thick film after a minute. Flavor has some nutty toasty malt, light brown sugar sweetness. Semi-dry finish, bitterness peaked at a 2-3. The aroma had stronger bready malt, less caramel. Light carbonation with a medium body. Solid.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: On tap at the brewery/distillery. Pours with a clear copper hued body with a small off-white head that lasts. Aromas are nutty, caramel, medium melanoidins, malty, and pretty clean. Very slight fruitiness, a touch of raisin and some munich like toasted, rich malt character. Flavors are malty, medium dry, bitterness balances malt to neutral, lightly herbal malt character, grainy and otherwise quite clean. Low carbonation, pretty dry with a nice toasted maltiness still intact. A pretty decent American made Marzen.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2014 Half pint at Old Grove Brewery.  Pours a amber orange color with a foamy tan head.  Aroma is of toasted malts, baked bread, and caramel.  Flavor is of toasted malts, bread, caramel, and some hops spiciness.  Has a medium body with a slightly watery mouthfeel and a short, sweet malty finish.  Overall, a pretty good Octo.
Tap. Rating #6. Dark amber with a light tan head. Rich malty aroma, caramel and very nice. Toasty and caramally with a slight bite. Really nice octo. (1466)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: On tap at brewery.  Dark red brown.  Spicy malt and caramel hints.  Dark for an Oktoberfest, but highly drinkable.  Lots of roastiness to it.  Hint of cinnamin?  Nice brew.
From a tap,red in color,carmel, malty,its ok, but isnt that great .Dont go crazy trying to find it.
A sweet malt aroma. Very very dark for an okto. Flavor is very sweet up front, lots of rich malt following. Certainly a very filling beer, but strainy and sugary, and doesnt seem much like an okto.

Sweet toasted malt aroma. Flavor starts rich caramel with light a nuttiness, a hint of burnt caramel, a moderately spicy bitterness and lightly sweet finish. Medium body is creamy with moderate carbonation.
clear copper red with a fizzy white head. Sweet caramel molasses and mildly nutty aroma and taste.
